content: The Act is titled the "Lower Brule Sioux Tribe Infrastructure Development Trust Fund Act". It includes findings related to the Act. Congress approved the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program under the Flood Control Act of 1944 to promote economic development, provide irrigation, and prevent floods. The Fort Randall and Big Bend projects are key components, generating hydropower and impounding water. These projects overlap with the Lower Brule Indian Reservation. Public Laws authorized the acquisition of Indian land on the Lower Brule Indian Reservation for the Fort Randall and Big Bend projects, impacting the Tribe's agricultural and pastoral lands along the Missouri River. Mitigation measures were put in place to address the effects of these projects on the reservation. The Army is authorized to protect, replace, and relocate essential facilities on the reservation for the Big Bend project. This includes schools, hospitals, offices, service buildings, employee quarters, roads, bridges, and related facilities. Additionally, a townsite for 50 homes with utilities and a community center for gatherings and tribal offices will be provided. The Lower Brule Indian Reservation lacks economic development despite the benefits of the Fort Randall and Big Bend projects. The Federal Government has not fulfilled its obligations to mitigate the effects on the tribe, hindering economic and social development. The Lower Brule Sioux Tribe's cultural preservation will be enhanced by addressing these issues. The Lower Brule Sioux Tribe's preservation will be improved by increased tribal participation in the benefits of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program, entitling them to additional benefits. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include the Fund as the Lower Brule Sioux Tribe Infrastructure Development Trust Fund, the Plan as the plan for socioeconomic recovery and cultural preservation, the Program as the power program of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program, the Secretary as the Secretary of the Interior, and the Tribe as the Lower Brule Sioux Tribe of Indians. The Lower Brule Sioux Tribe Infrastructure Development Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States. The Lower Brule Sioux Tribe Infrastructure Development Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States. Beginning in fiscal year 1998, the Secretary of the Treasury will deposit 25 percent of receipts from the Program into the Fund until it reaches $39,300,000. The funds will be invested in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The Secretary will establish an account to transfer interest payments to the Tribe. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers interest accrued on deposited amounts into a separate account. Starting the fiscal year after reaching a specified amount, funds are available to the Secretary of the Interior for use. The Secretary of the Treasury withdraws funds from the established account annually. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers interest accrued on deposited amounts into a separate account for the Secretary of the Interior to use. Funds are withdrawn annually for payments to the Tribe, which must be used for projects and programs outlined in a prepared plan. No per capita payments are allowed. The Tribe receives payments under section 4(d)(2) for a plan on socioeconomic recovery and cultural preservation. The plan must be prepared within 2 years, consulting with relevant authorities, and include identified costs, benefits, and plans for each component. The plan for the Lower Brule Indian Reservation includes an educational facility, comprehensive healthcare services, and a water system. The plan must be prepared within 2 years, consulting with relevant authorities, and include identified costs, benefits, and plans for each component. The plan for the Lower Brule Indian Reservation includes a water system for municipal, rural, and industrial use, recreational facilities at Lake Sharpe and other locations, and various projects for educational, social welfare, economic development, and cultural preservation. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds are authorized for this Act, including administrative expenses. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF PAYMENTS TO TRIBE. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF PAYMENTS TO TRIBE. No payment made to the Tribe under this Act shall impact any services or programs entitled to the Tribe or its members under Federal law. Payments will not affect power rates or diminish any rights or treaty obligations.
